08Sep2019 Sweet grain and cereal malts, creamy bread, light molasses, wheat. Hazy gold, medium, white head. Light sweet. More creamy grain and cereal malts, caramel, wheat, light bitter wet straw coming up, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Simplistic but fine. Can from City Beer.

Ar: Light cracker malt; a bit of hay. Ap: Orange and hazy; large white head with excellent retention, sits as a fine, moussey cap;  T: Light orange and lemon; cracker malt; very low sweetness; doughy, a bit of husk; pepper and more lemon; bitterness is medium, slightly leafy; finish is light malt, orange rind, and licorice. M: Medium-light body with high carbonation; dry finish. O: A refreshing, bright summer wheat; quaffable, but with a little edge of complexity on the malt side.

Bottle from Merchants. I can't believe I've never reviewed this. Aroma is wheat, orange peel, some pine, slight spice, a little earthy. Appearance is golden, off white head, unfiltered. Medium orange body, creamy white head. Citrus floral nose. A fuller mouthfeel than one would expect from appearances but not cloying. Hops and any associated bitterness are pushed well back.

Oberon is one of my favorites and a great beer. My only issue is that all the Bell’s beers taste the same as they all employ the same yeast. Citrusy and refreshing. Surpassed by a few like Great Raft’s Southern Drawl but very good drinker.

Oberon is an epic beer! (Bell's house yeast must be the secret ingredient?) All I know, is I have never tasted another beer quite like Oberon. When it releases each year at the end of March - our group drinks nothing else until it runs out in September. Oberon bottles, cans and mini kegs go with us on our boat, at the pool, picnics, hiking, weddings, etc. One of the few beers worthy of a Shakespeare reference.

DOC: 5/24/17

2015 BJCP Category: 1D American Wheat Beer


AROMA: General wheat/sourdough bread scent but with no distinctive character. Not sweet. Not much hop presence. Slight tang. 8/12

APPEARANCE: Extremely hazy orange body (7-9 SRM). Fairly large off-white foam retains and laces well enough. 2/3

FLAVOR: First half is mostly malty-bready flavor. Not especially sweet, or even robust for that matter. Some orange citrus flavor emerges as the apex akin to sweet orangepeel (though likely due to American hops). Low bitterness with minor spicy bite. Brief starchy aftertaste but otherwise clean. Palette is a bit mild even for this style. 16/20

MOUTHFEEL: Medium body; medium-high carbonation. Texture is very soft and creamy with smooth finish. Refreshing. A bit too potent for the style (and consumer expectations) at 5.8% ABV. Should be more sessionable. 4/5

OVERALL IMPRESSION: Probably the Godfather of the style, though not exactly the best example of it anymore. 7/10

TOTAL SCORE: 37/50

Overall, it’s pretty good. Keeps you guessing, sweet, mildly spicy. I don’t know if I’d call it a session beer, because of the ABV, but man, it’s good. Yeah, I would buy this again. I would also recommend this one.
Can from Kihoskh in Copenhagen. Fruity smell. Fruity smell with some bready malts. Feels like the hops has faded in this one, still drinkable though.

Can from Mikkeller Webshop. Light hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, wheaty, light fruity and light hoppy - grass. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. 250816

Color amarillo plátano con capa de espuma blanca de menos de un dedo de grosor. Carbonatación media tirando a alta. Restos de levadura/sedimentos/especias (diría lo último), altamente concentrados en el poso de la lata. Tan concentrados que cuando eché las últimas gotas el color amarillo pasó a ser blanco. Más bien parecía leche. No es algo que me eche para atrás, solo lo comento de pasada, para navegantes. El aroma es, en cierto modo, distinto al sabor y más pronunciado: trigo, especias. No capto malta y no capto lúpulo. El sabor es una variación del aroma, sin arriesgar. Sabe a trigo, de nuevo, a especias (no sé si cilantro), pero no capto lúpulo alguno. Unidimensional, refrescante y para de contar. No suelo hablar de precios, pero en este caso haber pagado 5 euros por algo tan plano (y viniendo de Bells) me hace recapacitar por enésima vez sobre mis gustos y los gustos de los demás. No voy a mentir, me la bebí entera porque costó lo que costó, pero es una total decepción.
Bottle. Orange color with medium white head, sediment in bottle. Aroma is malty, yeasty, wheaty with coriander, lemon peel and some citrus notes. Taste is malty, yeasty, medium bittery, lemony.

Burk från Mikkellers webbshop. Smak och doft av humle, jäst, vete, citrus, apelsin ohc persika. Lätt kropp och beska, fin sötma, mjuk och juiceig känsla, beska med smak av citrus- och apelsinskal. Gott!

From the bottle, pour is cloudy with sediment floating in the beer, the color is orange with a thick slightly off white head that lingures. The aroma is yeast, a little coriander and bread. The taste is malty, bread and raw wheat. There is a citrus note present reminiscent of lemon peal, but not very strong. The mouthfeel is thin, and the finish is malt.

Tap at Macs bar. Almost clear golden with fluffy white head. Mango, pineapple, sweet malts, apricot and orange. Quite fruity, with milky grain, almost like sweet bread. Medium sweet and almost medium bitter. Medium bodied.

Cloudy light orange with little head and minimal carbonation. Very sweet with some orange sherbet. Ok for a wheat beer.

Can:

Can. 
Hazy pale Golden pour, small White head.

Pours a hazy golden color with medium white head. Yeasty aroma, quite lagerish to be honest, citrusy, with lemon and cerealy. Taste follows it, lemony, yeasty and cerealy, some orange and slightly grapefruit.

500ml can from Beer Gonzo. Drunk while watching Flight of the Navigator. Pours hazy gold, good white head. Smooth with a good yeasty fruity character. Nice.

Can. Yellow cloudy body with white head. Aroma is yeast with some fruits some phenol. Taste is also very yeasty with ripe fruits, malts and hints of alcohol. Aftertaste is yeasty and malty slightly balanced by some hoppy bitterness. Was expecting much more.

Can. Pours light hazy golden with a rather small, white head. Malty aroma with notes of lemon. Feels quite thin, average carbonation. Very bland, almost like a mass produced pilsner. Abrupt. Very meh.
Can. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow very cloudy colour. Moderate malty and hopy and light yeasty aroma. Light bitter flavor. Average lioght bitter finish. Oily palate. boring beer.

On tap @ Mudville 9. Oh, I got an slice of orange in this one.. The beer itself is quite cloudy and, yeah I’m gonna say it, orange in color. A nice big bright white head placed on the top leaving some lacings. It smells nice and mild wheaty. Straws, some orange indeed. Hopefully not only from the slice.. It has a really standard taste this. It’s light oily in the mouth and has those big hard almost aggressive bubbles. Soft wheat sweet but really orange sweet. Mild cardboardy and dry in the finish. Nothing to memorable about this one really - except the look on my face when they jammed the orange slice on to it. 10.06.2015

Bottle. Wheat malt aroma with bright citrus fruitiness and spicy yeast notes. Pours cloudy golden colored with a thin white head that has decent retention and lacing. Starts with wheat malt flavor with citrus fruitiness. Finishes a bit dry, but quite refreshing with spicy yeast flavors joining the others. Nice wheat ale, good for warm summer days.

Decent beach beer but there are better out there. Aroma and taste of wheat, fruitiness, and hints of a Belgium beer. Clean finish. Just ok. Didn't find this that refreshing due to the Belgium like yeast influence. Not a repeat purchase.

Bottle poured into a shaker. Cloudy straw yellow with a thick white head and a lot of visible carbonation. Lots of wheat and a little yeast to the nose. Growler pour at trailer. Murky gold/amber color with ivory foam. Light pit fruit, mild sulfer, wheat bread, earthy aromas. Tart, tangy, citrusy tangerine, bready, herbal flavors---nice tangy drying finish___good.
Crisp fizzy and dry, with a lovely puffy body. A mellow sweetness, through a predominantly bready flavor. A nice bitter tingle in the center of the tongue too. Summer swiggin’
Can. Pours hazy orange/golden with off-white head. Aroma is sweet fruity wheat. Taste is sweet hoppy fruitless with a hoppy finish. Pretty good.

Bottle at Gollem in Antwerp (along with 77ships), first time for me, though this is a classic among American wheat ales. Cobweb-lacing, off-white, moussy head over a hazy yellow golden beer with slight peachy hue. Aroma is unfortunately ruined by a lot of DMS (cooked cauliflower), which I am very sensitive to and which I did not in the least expect in a Bell’s; after this sulfuric odor fades a bit, I get green banana, soap, white bread, sugared pineapple, peach, mango, yeast. Fruity onset, bit estery with peach, pineapple and gooseberry impressions, medium carbo, supple malt sweet body with soapy and light sourish wheat, light hoppy finish with a somewhat herbal character but not as aromatic (let alone bittering) as it could have been - though like all wheat beer styles, American wheat is not characterized by huge hop quantities anyway, of course. And thus this beer ends mostly with malt sweetness, a bit grainy even, and on the thin side. I expected a whole lot more considering how great Bell’s other beers are and the DMS largely ruined this for me so this was the big disappointment of the day, I’m afraid...

355 ml. bottle @ Gollem. Date says 03/02/16. Hazy golden, little white patchy head. Nose is big paper, some cardboard, there is low orange peel, mango, apricot, low grain,… Taste is bitter insecticide, herbal, paper, apricot, lots of paper, low cardboard, low esters & orange peel, tad bitter herbs. Body is bit dull, oily, paper. Not really getting the high score here, it doesn’t have a pleasant wheat base, hop presence is far too low, most bitterness and taste is paper and mothballs, meh at best this one.
Yellow color with white foam ring. Light hoppy nose. Sweet, yet light bitter taste with a little weird hop mixture. Dry bitter finish with some tartness in the aftertaste.

Sample while checking out the expo at HomeBrewCon.
Slightly hazy light yellow with a decent white head. spicy earthy sweet bready with a cereal quality to it. Easy to drink, glad to have tried it.

Nice beer.

The flavor profile is very good but lacks a bit of complexity. Intensity and balance are outstanding. Light lemon and wheat cracker arrive initially. Mid palate delivers a subtle bitterness and an equally subtle biscuit sweetness. Clove becomes the main component from the middle on riding over the wheat. The finish is somewhat crisp and light clove lingers.

Easy drinking wheat with a slight spice to the taste.

Review based on the BJCP2015 guidelines (style 1D). Bottle 35.5 cl - Batch 0851238. AROMA: prominent hop aroma with traditional american character (slightly citric / pine / rustic), with a moderate to low malt character (faint wheat). APPEARANCE: pale gold and hazy. average white noussey head with moderate retention. TASTE: initial hop flavor similar to aroma (slight citric and rustic), followed by a moderate-low sweet malty character (faint wheat). moderate bitterness that slightly lingers beyond a semi-dry finish. PALATE: medium to medium-low body with moderate-high carbonation. OVERALL: an american wheat ale with all aspects within the style (clean yeast, etc), and with a prominent hop presence but not overwhelming. it would benefit with a more wheat presence.
33cl bottle from firma bier. Light hazy dark gold to orange color. Thin white head. Body is thin, quite crispy. Taste is medium bitter, low sweet. Aroma is orange, lemon, malt, light yeast.

Straw color, total clarity, very slight haze. Actively rising carbonation but a sliver of a white head that doesn’t look very promising. Nice touch of spices on the nose such as coriander complemented by a lemon/lime citric aroma. I feel like the percentage of wheat in the grist is not much more than 20%, but I could be wrong. On the entry it feels a little too spritzy and stripped of flavor, but it is still far better than most American wheat ales I’ve tasted. More than decent mouthfeel and a great summer drinker for anyone.

1 pint can @ Timo A. Could not interpret the date.

4424

Bottle at home. Aroma is sweetish biscuity malt, floral, wheat, bubblegum, fruits, dough, yeast, spices, apricots. Flavour is over moderate sweet with a little bitterness in the finish. Thanks Greg for sharing the bottle! A bottle about 6 months old or so.

A delicious wheaty-easy-to-drink beer. I know people go crazy when this hits shelves again each summer, and I only had it a couple of times a couple of years ago, but I remember it being the quintessential summer beer: light in body, light in color, and kind of sweet.
Finally a wheat beer without wheat in taste. I like it! Well balanced in different styles (?), anyhow a good stuff. B@H

Spicy, sour, yeasty wheat beer aroma from a murky medium yellow body with a foamy white head. Lots of good wheat taste here with a full body that makes this more substantial than a lot of wheat beer. Some cloves in the middle but not strong and a nice alcohol bite for a wheat beer. Finishes slightly sweet and yeasty. Very refreshing and very good.

Can to goblet. Aroma is corn, wheat, grass, hay. A bit musty. Touch of fruit, maybe orange, deeper down. Appearance is Light yellow, mildly cloudy...medium white head. Taste is grass and light citrus. A shy aftertaste. Feel is a touch pasty, but smooth. A bit underwhelmed.

5.8%ABV. Wheat Ale.

Poured out of the bottle a light amber.  8ºSRM.

Nose is beery and wheaty.  There is some fruity herbaceousness to the nose.  Some residual dusty floury aromas.

Mouthfeel is watery.  There are some light toasty flavors with wheat toast coming up most prominently.    

Light hop finish.

Overall, a light drinking adequately put together ale
Gold with thin beige head; aroma is mild slightly fruity raspberries; flava is sweet raspberry and subtle grain; feels medium creamy soft but lively fizz; finishes dry tangy
Nothing bad or special here. Pretty typical wheat ale. Heavy wheat flavor, low malt flavor and some hop in the background. Middle of the road well made wheat ale.

The aroma is pretty good, you can feel a strong floral notes, but for a wheat beer I would have expected the nice banana or cloves aromas but actually they are not in there. Floral hop with pleasing citrus note. This can be hard to find by its strong following is putting it on more and more shelves. Even saw it at a wedding!! Great breakfast beer!

Bottle from Beer Cartel 240915. You don’t see many of Bell’s beers in this part of the world so I snap them up when I can. Weighty number this one with solid colour and a head that fades. Good strong body and a fair bit or fruitiness happening.

Poured from a 16oz can into a pub glass. Packaged 5/15/15.

Aroma - Bubblegum sweetness, cereal (Captain Crunch?), dare I say orange creamsicle? 

Appearance - Hazy, deep orange.

Taste - Matches the nose completely with a balancing bitterness. Hops, in their own right, bring out bright orange-like flavors. Incredibly unique. If I were a kid again, wondering what a beer smells like, I’d assume it’d be something like this. 

Palate - Creamy (emphasis), medium bodied.

Overall - Lives up to the hype and more. In a style that typically lacks any real oomph, and often leaves me wondering why I just didn’t have a hefeweizen instead, this one is a no-brainer.
12 fl oz bottle. Pours murky golden with a medium white head. Aroma of some yeast, pale malt, orange. Taste is slightly yeasty, pale malt, orange, spices.

Transfer from BA review on 5-5-13-

 Served on tap in a pint glass

 Appearance – The beer pours a very hazy golden amber color with a one half finger white head. The head has a moderate level of retention, fading over about a 5 min time period to leave a lighter level of lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell – The nose is quite heavy of an orange citrus mixed with lots of grainy wheat. Along with these smells is a yeasty nature as well as a little bit of cardamom and clove spice. Rounding these smells out are some grassy and more herbal hop aromas giving a rather nice mellow smell overall.

 Taste – The taste begins, as the nose would have suggested, with a wheaty and orange citrus flavor. As the flavor advances, the yeasty flavors come along and bring with them flavors of a light corriander spice and some banana. A grassy flavor comes to the tongue more toward the middle of the taste and gets slightly stronger as the taste advances to the end. Along with the grassy flavor, the wheaty flavor grows in strength and becomes more grainy with more yeasty flavors coming to the tongue as well. With the mix of flavors that reside at the end, a rather grainy wheat and yeasty citrus flavor is left to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel- The body of the beer is on the average to slightly creamier side for a brew of 5.8% abv with a carbonation level that is rather average to slightly above average. The creamier body is very nice for the wheaty and grainy flavors of the brew while the citrus is nicely accentuated by the moderate to slightly higher carbonation. 

 Overall – A nice drinking American Pale ale with a good blend of wheat, yeast, citrus and grassy flavors. Rather tasty.

OCCASION: Shark Week 2014 kicks off...with another mockumentary?!...APPEARANCE: hazy to the point of opaqueness; burnt yellow body; simple white head; little effervescence... AROMA: some pitchy yeast and bubblegum is planted in a malty base; gentle hops round out the profile ... PALATE: light body, slightly active; soft from tart to finish, barely suggesting an ale in the wheat; highly drinkable... TASTE: bright,slightly sou lemon and light malts; some pepper and clove arrive late;remarkably flavorful for a refresher...OVERALL: much better than Shark of Darkness, much to my disappointment of the latter; Oberon is crisp, remarkably balanced, and on par with Victory’s Whirlwind--a worthy case mate for Bell’s Two Hearted...

Very good beer. Light enough to drink when it’s hot outside, and perfect for a sunny day. I also enjoy this all year round because it has a very nice wheat flavor, but the yeast helps add the citrus.

Oberon packs a lot of goodness into its cloudy yellow body. It’s as easy on the nose as it is on the eyes with a soft bready aroma and some spicy cloves thrown in for good measure. The flavor has some mild yeast funk, citrusy hops, and candy-like wheat malt. The crisp, lively carbonation keeps the body light and refreshing. Oberon may not be Bell’s boldest or most complex ale, but it’s one of the best examples of an American style pale wheat ale.
Pours a cloudy golden amber color with a slight white head. Slight citrus aroma. The texture is smooth, light and tasty. Perfect is everyday and very easy to see why it is considered so good.

12 oz bottle into a shaker. Decanted the pour, leaving most of the yeast in the bottom the bottle, but still some yeast in suspension which is spot on for a german style wheat bear. This feels like a slightly more hoppy version of the summer wheat beers you can find in Bavaria. Smells of citrus and summer! I love this beer on a hot summer day.
Poured from a bottle. Golden amber with an ivory head. Aroma is grainy with a hint of citrus. Similar taste. Body is light with crisp carbonation. Good, but not a standout.

This beer had a hint of an unpleasant aroma which I thought resembled canned tuna. Fresh, high-quality canned tuna, but that’s not a smell I want in my beer. Besides that, it was rather typical, if unremarkable, for a wheat beer. Only a mild hop presence. The flavor was slightly muddled, a hint of sweetness and some bitterness...moderate body. As faint as the fishy aroma was, I found it off-putting and it interefered in my ability to enjoy this otherwise middle-of-the-road brew.
Hazy light orange pour with a frothy white head. Smells wheaty with citrus. Taste is citrus, wheat and some light bitterness.

A very refreshing citrusy aroma that is orange in color and very pleasant to the nose. An orange wheat in taste and is also very pleasant on the palate. Overall it’s a very drinkable summer ale which is definately a beer that you can have many on a hot day.

12 oz bottle poured into a shaker. The very clean, light aromas of flowers, grass, lemon, lime, orange (I guess general citrus would be appropriate, although I’m pretty sure I’m picking up the distinct differences), and even peaches give this a true springtime feel. There’s also some pine and a touch of toasted grain underneath. The beer is a very murky apricot flesh color (kinda dull yellow-brown) with a fluffy white head that retains well and leaves a light, but puffy lace jutting out along the sides of the glass (should anything less be expected from a wheat ale?). For a wheat ale, this actually has a significant bitter bite to it, I’d say a medium level bitterness (lighter end of medium) with a medium / medium-light, dull sweetness. The body is medium light and full of lots of fizzy carbonation. The texture is fairly thin and watery, but it’s very crisp and refreshing with a dried citrus peel and grain finish. Some pine appears at the finish too, but disappears at the aftertaste; which is mostly clean except for a refreshing dry citrus peel that doesn’t hang around too long.

Pours an unfiltered golden orange with little bits of sediment. Fizzy white head settles into a sticky cap that leaves nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is boiled peanuts, citrus rind, fresh cut grass, lemon zest, and some herbal notes that I can’t quite put my finger on. Honestly it has a little bit of a funk to it that I wasn’t expecting. Flavor is lighter than the nose would suggest. Orange peel, coriander, slight hop bitterness on the back end rounded out by some sweet malts. I just ate so I may have to come back to this one later and do the flavor a little more justice. Mouthfeel is great. Perfectly carbonated. Overall a decent summertime brew.

Light retention and no lacing. Smells of bran cereal, wheat and grains. Tastes of grained cereal, earth and slight citrus zest. Wheaty aftertaste.

Reviewed from notes.
The appearance had a hazy pale yellow colored body and left a one finger white head that died within thirty seconds. Some nice ringy lacing was left. Some light slow carbonation was seen rising.
The smell had some moderate flavors of wheat along with notes of orange and lemon.
The taste was basically the same with a slight added hops to it and a nice bit of light acceptable sourness to it.
The palate was about a light with a decent amount of carbonation hitting the tongue, but in a nice and acceptable way for the style.
Overall, this is a good summer beer that is quite drinkable and makes me want to move back to Michigan just so I can have it in the summers.

This is my summer beer.

A big part of Oberon is the presentation. If you drink it straight, it’s an above average wheat beer, but not anything to crow about. But try this: 

Pour the beer in a glass. Slice a quarter inch thick piece of an orange, cut it in half, and put it on the lip of the glass. When you sip, try to get the aroma of the orange peel. The blend of fresh orange peel alongside the flavor of the beer is exquisite.

Try it. Or don’t. More for me.

Beautiful wheat, cloudy, grainy beer; sediment reminds you that God gave us livers to filter.

If I were ever to get a tattoo on my face, it would be of the sun from the Oberon bottle. I love this beer.
